63.text:
There are four themes in the A level specification.
Theme 1 looks at markets, consumers and firms,

72.text:

environment, including introducing life in

79.text:
a global economy. These themes have the same
content for both the AS and A level qualification.

87.text:
Theme 3 builds on the content in Theme 2,
exploring the global economy in more depth.

96.text:
Theme 4 builds on Theme 1 content, exploring
how markets work. This theme includes a look

105.text: at risk and the financial sector.

108.text:
There are two externally examined papers for
the AS qualification; Theme 1 is assessed

120.text:
in Paper 1 and Theme 2 is assessed in Paper
2.

126.text:
The content for Theme 1 and Theme 2 is the
same for the AS and A level qualifications.

qualifications are separate, you can co-teach

For most students, economics is a new subject

702.text:
Highlights include:
How consumers are influenced by and respond

706.text:
to changes in prices and incomes.
Small firm survival in competitive markets.

715.text:
An introduction to developed, emerging and
developing economies.

723.text:
This topic focuses on the motivations for
the growth of firms and the methods firms

731.text:
may use to achieve growth.
The objectives of firms, including profit

737.text:
and share price maximisation, are explored,
along with increasing brand awareness and

743.text:
market share. The idea that the growth of
firms is linked to competitive advantage in

749.text:
a free market is also highlighted, along with
the impact these objectives may have on stakeholders.

758.text:
Research and development (R&D) technical or
scientific research that is undertaken with

765.text:
a view to introducing new or improved products
and services is examined in the context of

772.text:
establishing and maintaining competitive advantage.
The increasing importance of buying and selling

779.text:
online is explored and the section ends with
a look at the reasons why small firms continue

785.text:
to thrive despite the advantages accruing
to large firms.

792.text:
The focus of this topic is on the relationship
between the firm and the consumer.

802.text:
Activities that firms engage in to maximise
demand for goods and services, as well as

809.text:
the factors which impact on the consumers'
willingness and ability to purchase those

814.text:
goods and services, are explored. Pricing
strategies are considered, as is the idea

821.text:
that the non-price competition (which students
could relate to as the marketing mix in business)

827.text:
can be adapted for different markets. The
concept of price elasticity of demand is used

834.text:
to help students understand and analyse the
relationship between price level, demand and

841.text:
sales revenue. The concept of income elasticity
of demand is used to help students understand

848.text:
and analyse the relationship between income
level, demand and sales revenue.

857.text:
The topic focuses on the ways in which firms
can reduce their costs in order to become

866.text:
more competitive.
Productivity is examined and the strategies

871.text:
and procedures available to firms to improve
productivity are explored. The impact of relative

879.text:
efficiency on sales revenue and costs is also
considered.

887.text:
This topic introduces students to life in
a global economy.

894.text:
Globalisation is the ongoing integration of
countries on a political, economic and social

902.text:
level. A definition from Peter Jay, the former
BBC Economics Editor, is: 'The ability to

909.text:
produce any good (or service) anywhere in
the world, using raw materials, components,

916.text:
capital and technology from anywhere, sell
the resulting output anywhere, and place the

922.text:
profits anywhere.' Although it is not in itself
new, the last three decades have seen a huge

930.text:
increase in globalisation, leading to increasing
trade and rising prosperity across the globe,

938.text:
with the growing power of transnational corporations
producing and selling in developing economies

944.text:
and emerging markets. China and India, for
example, have become significant economic

950.text:
powers, and other countries are growing rapidly.
Allied with rapid technological change and

957.text:
improved transport and communications, the
global economy has seen a major structural

963.text:
change which is continuing to affect individuals,
firms and economies.

973.text:
This topic extends topic 2.4 to look at the
macroeconomic environment within which firms

983.text:
operate.
Established macroeconomic concepts are defined

988.text:
and developed to encourage students to understand
that firms do not operate in isolation from

995.text:
broader national and international economic
forces and trends.

1003.text:
A government's economic policy choices will
be determined by their own short- and long-term

1013.text:
political interests. The aim of this topic
is to explore the reasoning behind policy

1019.text:
decisions and the likely conflicts between
policy objectives.

1025.text:
There are commonly five main economic aims
for government:

1030.text:
1. steady and sustainable rate of increase
of national output (economic growth)

1037.text:
2. low level of unemployment
3. low and stable rate of inflation

1045.text:
4. favourable balance of payments position
5. equitable distribution of income.

1055.text:
The emphasis a government places on each of
these areas will largely determine their fiscal
